It is unfortunate that the militant sections of the union may approach any person who takes an opposing view and seek to intimidate ordinary workers and that those workers should have to live with that intimidation as part of their workplace and their daily lives. I ask: what does any ordinary worker do if they know that they and their family run the risk of being threatened in their opposition to any proposed industrial action? It is a sad reflection on some unions that, in an age when we are seeking to eliminate bullying from our school playgrounds, there still exists an environment of fear being inflicted by union heavies upon ordinary Australians who are simply trying to earn a living and provide for their family, and simply trying to exercise their democratic right in the workplace.

Making these Australians vote in a public forum does nothing for their democratic right. It does nothing for their ability to have their say. Make that vote a secret ballot and then the true will of employees can ultimately be measured. The current workplace relations environment also runs the risk of dragging innocent participants into this dispute. Often it is the case that one particular firm has no relevance to another firm many miles away but the second firm may be dragged into the industrial action. Despite there being two separate companies with two separate workplaces, the union movement attempts to drag company B in when the real problem exists with company A, and there may be no relevance between the two organisations. This sort of situation clearly discriminates against the rights of employees in individual workplaces to have the terms of their specific agreement considered without the camouflage of the wider union agenda.

We all know that trade unions will drag the interests and goodwill of employees from one company into the industrial action being taken in another company. One only has to look at the conduct of many trade unions over time to see the ramifications of this. Industrial action by trade unions often overlooks the specific needs of the workers and is purely based on an agenda decided by a centralised, metropolitan based hierarchy which is immune to the needs of individual workers. The reality is that many of the specific concerns of employees can be resolved with management of the business and all parties can get on and be productive, get on and earn a living and get on and strike a blow for Australiaâno lost work days, no lost wages, no jeopardising of existing and future contracts. Good management wants its employees to work in an environment which is going to make them the most productive.

Why should a trade union impose its will for industrial action on employees of company A because of matters relating to an agreement in company B? To ensure that employees are not made a pawn in the trade union game, employees must, by law, be given the opportunity to vote on whether they take industrial action, but to vote in a secret ballot. The only way employees can do this without being personally intimidated or without the fear of being intimidated in the workplace, without the fear of recrimination, without the fear of having to toe a specific union line, is to be able to have a secret ballot at the workplace level. I agree with the view that over time such a recourse to secret ballots where protected action is an issue would contribute to developing a culture of employee involvement in the workplace and in workplace decision making. I do not know what members opposite have to fear from the thought of the exercise of democratic rights in the workplace.

It is interesting to note that other developed countries across the world have already adopted similar legislation. It is not exactly the sameâand the member for Brisbane always seeks to draw distinctions between what we are proposing here and that other legislationâbut similar legislation has been put in place around the world. Those measures are consistent with the standards set down by the International Labour Organisation. It is the ILO's role to formulate international labour standards which set minimum standards for a whole range of things, including basic labour rights, freedom of association, the right to organise, collective bargaining, abolition of forced labour, equality of opportunity and treatment, and other standards and regulations regulating conditions across the entire spectrum of work related issues. All of these standards for workers are protected in legislation in Australia. I believe that in achieving consistency with ILO standards this bill has solid credibility and is in the mutual interests of employees and business.

The secret ballot provisions in this bill are also consistent with the measures in place in the legislative instruments in the United Kingdom, Canada, Japan, Germany and Ireland. For example, section 87.3(1) of the Canada Labour Code, which was instigated in 1998, says:

quote.para: (1) Unless a lockout not prohibited by this Part has occurred, a trade union may not declare or authorize a strike unless it has, within the previous sixty days, or any longer period that may be agreed to in writing by the trade union and the employer, held a secret ballot vote among the employees in the unit and received the approval of the majority of the employees who voted.

speech.para: Sixty days: that is how it is in Canada at the moment. The Labour Code goes on:

quote.para: (2) Unless a strike not prohibited by this Part has occurred, an employers' organization may not declare or cause a lockout unless it has, within the previous sixty days, or any longer period that may be agreed to in writing by the trade union and the employers' organization, held a secret ballot vote among the employers who are members of the organization and received the approval of the majority of the employers who voted.

speech.para: It adds:

quote.para: (3) A vote held under subsection (1) or (2) must be conducted in such a manner as to ensure that those employees or employers who are eligible to vote are given a reasonable opportunity to participate in the vote and to be informed of the results.

speech.para: And it goes on and on. In the United Kingdom there have been measures in place since 1984 for secret ballots. Interestingly enough, they were retained by the Blair Labour government, which is a Labour Party actually in government at a national level. The measures were retained by the Blair Labour government in its industrial relations reforms of 1999. The Blair government has taken the very appropriate stance of not only allowing secret ballots but also addressing the legal status of ballots in which some voters have found to have been intimidated or induced into taking a particular stance. In fact, in the United Kingdom, section 232A of the Employee Relations Act of 1999 clearly spells out that the industrial action is not considered as having the support of the ballot if a person:

quote.para: ... was induced by the trade union to take part or, as the case may be, to continue to take part in the industrial action.

speech.para: That act actually takes account of the fact that trade unions may seek to induce workers to take part in industrial action. We think that democracy, rather than forcing the hand of the workers, is the way to go. Having workers being able to exercise their free will is the best way to go forward and the best way for productivity. This point demonstrates that, across party lines, secret ballot provisions are sensible and constructive. The UK Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations noted that those provisions have the support of union leaders in that country; and that is interesting to know.

However, I am sure that, in keeping with the traditions of the Australian Labor Party, the members sitting opposite are feeling rather squeamish about these changes. No doubt they are under pressure from the unionsâwhether they be the 60-40 unions or the 50-50 unions; I am not sure whichâto go down yet another path against job productivity, business, economic growth, commonsense and democracy. The experience in the United Kingdom of having these provisions has been a significant reduction in strike activities, the secret ballot having given union members a direct say in the authorisation and conduct of industrial action. I have said it before: how can members be free to exercise their democratic right without that secret ballot?

The Workplace Relations Amendment (Secret Ballots for Protected Action) Bill 2002 is a progressive step, and one which will provide for improved productivity and democracy and will allow workers to have their say. It is great for employees, employers, the business environment and the productivity of this country. I certainly commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âThe purpose of the Workplace Relations Amendment (Secret Ballots for Protected Action) Bill 2002 is to amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to require the conduct of a secret ballot by union members and non-union members as a prerequisite for gaining authorisations from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to take protected industrial action against an employer during enterprise bargaining negotiations. The Bills Digest states:

quote.para: This is to ensure that those participating in the action have decided upon the action and have not been misled by union officials.

speech.para: That is an unfortunate phrase. The Bills Digest does a great job in preparing legislation briefs for us members, but it seems as though that is taking a misleading position in prejudging what might happen. It is, unfortunately, suggesting that this legislation is necessary because union officials mislead their members. As an ex-union officialâand there is another one sitting at the tableâI can say that we simply do not. It is a different environment and culture. We do have a show of hands, but everyone has a say and there is no pressure applied. It is a different but interesting democratic culture.

It is an insult, nevertheless, to say this. It ignores the fact that, in effect, employers have more opportunity to mislead their own employees than union officials do. I am not saying that employers do necessarily mislead, but they certainly have greater opportunity to influence their employees than union officials do. Employers have unfettered access to their employees during working hours and they have the power to hire and fire, which is a great influence over their own employees. They have far more opportunity to mislead than do union officials. I use the word `mislead' in the same context as `influence', and that is what happens.

This legislation shows that the government are pursuing a very biased industrial relations agenda and using this as a political tactic to demonise unions and union officials, in the same way that they have demonised refugees, unemployed people and people on disability support pensions. It appears that the government demonise any group they want to attack before they attack them.

This type of legislation was first proposed in the Workplace Relations Amendment (Less Secure Employment) Bill 1999. At the same time the 1999 budget introduced funding for the partial cost of conducting these ballots, assuming of course that the balance of the cost would be borne by the applicant union. The bill, nevertheless, failed the Senate. The government then introduced schedules of this bill as a series of separate bills and thus the Workplace Relations Amendment (Secret Ballots for Protected Action) Bill 2000 was introduced into the House of Representatives and then referred to the Senate, where it suffered the same fate as the earlier legislation. This is a case of try, try again and, if it does not work, then hit somebody over the back of the head with a cricket bat.

The biased nature of the government's industrial relations agenda can be seen by the comments of the current minister for union bashing, the member for Warringah. When speaking of this legislation, he said:

quote.para: It will ensure that the right to protected industrial action is not abused by union officials pushing agendas unrelated to the workers at the workplace concerned.

speech.para: Only a very creative mind or a mad conspiracy theorist would envisage a situation where workers would be prepared to lose wages over issues unrelated to the workplace. I do not want to accuse the minister of having a creative mind. The proposals in this legislation, however, are unnecessarily complex. A discussion paper on the implementation of the Orwellian named Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999, released by the previous minister for children overboard, stated:

quote.para: Protected action will be preceded by a secret ballot process overseen by the AIRC. Ballots will normally be conducted by post, although applications may be made for attendance ballots in appropriate circumstances. An application for a secret ballot will only be able to be made during a bargaining period and will be required to include a range of information, such as the proposed certified agreement to which a secret ballot relates, the group of employees or members who are to be balloted, and the question or questions to be asked in the ballot. The AIRC will be empowered to determine whether a ballot should or should not proceed. Before ordering a ballot the AIRC would need to be satisfied that, among other things, the parties have been genuinely bargaining.
Members of organisations making agreements (or the employees to be covered in the case of non-union agreements) would be eligible to vote in a ballot.

speech.para: Are there any questions so far? Does anyone follow it? I must admit that I am a bit lost. The point not covered in this statement by the then minister for workplace relations is: if it is necessary to hold a secret ballot to determine if industrial action should take place, it obviously follows that it is necessary to hold a secret ballot to determine if and when a resumption of work should take place. One goes with the other. If there is a secret ballot and people make the decision to go out in dispute, how do they know when to return to work? They have to have another ballotâa postal ballot, I guess. If that is the case then would the 40 per cent quota apply, as the legislation states? What would happen if the people in dispute did vote to return to work but then only 37 per cent voted? Do they stay out? It is total confusion.

Another point not answered is this: what happens if the employer is not genuinely bargaining? The most likely cause of industrial action is in fact the employer not bargaining in good faith. If there is no genuine bargaining, the AIRC, it seems, cannot order a secret ballot. You would have the AIRC denying an application to take industrial action precisely because the employer is not bargaining in good faith. It is typical of the twisted logic of this government when it comes to workers' rights to withdraw their labour. Clearly the government's industrial relations agenda is complementary to its political agenda.

The trade union movement has critical ties with the Australian Labor Party. We are proud of this. This is a piece of Australian history. It began years ago, when the working people of this country determined that they wanted a political party to look after their interests. I believe that this is a piece of history that the Liberal Party is jealous of. But the relationship is pragmatic more than dictatorial. History has shown that at the end of the day, after due process, Labor governments do what they consider is in the best interests of the country or the state. Labor governments are not dictated to by any particular group or the trade union movement. For example, who would claim that the sale of the Commonwealth Bank or Qantas or the recent changes to workers compensation in New South Wales were policies advocated by the trade union movement? Certainly nobody in their right mind would. There were differences of opinion and of course the Labor government introduced what they thought was the appropriate legislation at the time.

The trade union movement does have an influenceâthere is no question about thatâbut not exclusively. More importantly, I would suggest, employer organisations and organisations such as the National Farmers Federation have far more influence over Liberal and National Party policy than has the union movement over the ALP. There is a definite double standard in Australian politics when it comes to the union movement and the ALP: it is perfectly reasonable, it seems, to have an NFF controlled National Party in charge of agriculture and trade policy, but there is outrage when a union official says anything remotely connected with industrial relations.

If you want a conflict of interest, you need to look no further than the member for Wide Bay, a farmer who is the minister for agriculture. Let me make it clear: I am not having a go at the minister for agriculture, I am simply pointing out the double standards that exist in this place. The minister for industrial relations might also take a glance along his own frontbench. One of his colleagues is an ex-president of one of the most militant trade unions in the country. I am referring to the member for Bradfield, who is the current minister for education and an ex-president of the AMA. Of course they do not call themselves a union, so they are all right! Maybe if the AMWU changed their name to the AMWA, the minister would stop abusing them, but I doubt it.

The Minister for Employment and Workplace Relationsâwho does not actually believe in workplace relations, just workplace dictatorshipsâhas continually abused the processes of this House to attack members of trade unions. What he fails to understand is that trade union officials are people just like those in any other professionâdoctors, motor mechanics, builders labourersâwho have families, who live in communities, who are members of clubs, churches, sporting teams and so on. They are people who have spent many years on the factory floor or in the office or in their particular profession doing their training, their apprenticeship and mastering their trade or profession before moving after a period of time into the trade union movement to represent their members. Since that time they have spent every working day trying to get a better deal for their fellow workers, battling on behalf of their neighbours and colleagues, their friends and complete strangers, protecting their rights and improving their lot. I am proud of the work performed by unionists and I make no apologies for it. What has the minister done himself except denigrate and pour scorn on ordinary people, on ordinary workers and on the trade unions' efforts to help?

There is another double standard at play in Australian politics. The minister would have you believe that everybody on Labor's front bench is an ex-union official. He might be interested to know that there are 10 ex-union officials on the front bench of the opposition out of thirtyâthat is, about 30 per cent. You could include a further three who have worked for the trade union movement but were not an official of a union. That takes the percentage up to 43 per cent. The minister says that that is outrageous, that that is domination by the unions. What does he say of his own frontbench and his own profession? Nothing, of course. The truth is too embarrassing to mention. Let us have a look at the figures. Of the 30 ministers in the Howard government, 17 are lawyers. That is 57 per cent. Whichever way you cut the cake, there are more lawyers on the front bench of the government than there are unionists on the front bench of the opposition.

The minister likes to talk about union representation in the Senate on the Labor side. Maybe the minister would care to consider the fact that of the 10 ministers in the Senate eight of them are lawyersâthat is, a whopping 80 per cent of their Senate frontbench are lawyers. Talk about domination! It is rank hypocrisy on the part of the minister and the government to damn our side for its union involvement while the government benches are jammed packed with lawyers. Of course, as the old adage goes, if you put 17 lawyers in a room you will get 43 different opinions on a particular case. It is interesting to note that the 11 lawyers on the government's backbench justice committee managed a win over the 17 lawyers on the government's front bench when it came to the antiterrorist laws, forcing the amendments we will soon be seeing. I could say that some lawyers are bad, just as the minister saysâI have not heard him actually praise any unionists, so I am assuming that he thinks all unionists are badâthat all unionists are bad. I would probably have more support for my statement than he does for his, but I would also say that all generalisations are bad and the minister needs to stop using them.

I might also point out that, while there are a number of ex-union officials on our side of the chamber, there is also an incredible diversity of experience. We may be former union officials, but we also had careers prior to becoming union officials. We have teachersâthe member for Brisbane who spoke before me from this side was a school teacherâengineers, builders, transport workers, metal workers and clerks, and we have people from a dozen other professions across every industry and from all facets of the community. That would make us, I believe, probably more representative of the community than the domination of lawyers on the other side of the House. The breadth of workplace experience is something that the government side of the House can only envy, and what they cannot possess or cannot understand they try to destroy. They are the true Luddites of Australian politics.

This bill is unworkable and it only serves to deny the rights of ordinary workers to withdraw their labour if they so choose. The right to strike is a basic right for every worker and the government's attempt to take away this basic right will come to nothing. This bashing of unions, in particular, by the ministerâalthough the few speakers from the government side that have spoken in this debate this afternoon also appear to hold a very biased view of the union movement; I think it is based on ignorance; it is probably because they have never been involved in a union activity or been a member of a union and therefore speak through ignoranceâwill not succeed, because the hard-fought gains won by the union movement over more than a century of hard work on behalf of every worker in Australia will not be taken away easily.

What the minister and the government fail to understand is that unions are an integral part of our society. They are an inevitable by-product of the government's economic rationalist version of capitalism. Their system allows employers to run roughshod over workers. Their playing field is not level: everything is shifted in the direction of the employer under this system. Workers, if left on their own, inevitably lose out while the government and this minister sit on the sidelines and cheer. Unions help to even the score. If employers never tried to rip off workers, if employers always looked after the health and safety of their employees while at work, if employers always dealt fairly and equitably with their workers when it came to wages, there would be no need for unions. But the sad reality is that employers do not always do this. Unfortunately, the government's legislation encourages them to be overly severe on union membership and union members' rights to protect their wages and conditions. Of course, not all employers are bad, and I can say that as a union official for over 27 years. More often than not, most employers are good employersâyou do get the odd bad ones and I might just deal with them in finalising my speech. A lot of employers do deal fairly with their workers and they do look after their occupational health and safety. That is why those workplaces do not have union issues to contend with.

The unions step in only when conditions are threatened. When Rio Tinto sacked 190 coalminers at Hunter Valley No. 1 without any word of warning and without any proper process, the union stepped in. The union was vilified by the government for doing so but it fought, it won the case and then had to keep fighting the appeals. After a three-year battle, only this month the union won a settlement for its members. Individually the members who had been unfairly dismissedâand remember they won the case initiallyâcould not have kept fighting the case by themselves. Rio Tinto is a huge corporation and it was willing to spend millions of dollars appealing the umpire's decision. Individual workers who have just been sacked are not in that kind of position: they do not have the millions of dollars that Rio Tinto has to fight cases like this on their own. They need help, and where are they going to get that help? I will answer that by simply saying that without the union Rio Tinto would have gotten away with it.

Unions have created a great legacy in this country for workers. We no longer live in a feudal society where workers are chattels to be used and discarded on a whim. Unions have fought for over a century, winning the rights and entitlements of ordinary working men and women. They should be congratulated, not vilified. The standard of living we experience in Australia today is a direct by-product of the union movement. The conditions and wages that workers currently have, which give us our standard of living, are the result of the actions and hard work of unionists and the union movement. Any attack on the union movement is an attack on the standard of living of ordinary Australian families, and the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations knows this. For all his rhetoric and his Orwellian newspeak, I believe this minister for workplace relations is firmly entrenched on the side of the employer, to the detriment of ordinary Australian workers.

This bill is unworkable, and I have a sneaking suspicion that the minister knows this. He is a student of elections and electoral processes and he must know that, in terms of outcomes, postal ballots are among the most inefficient and unreliable forms of voting methods. A postal ballot will take an inordinate amount of time to conduct. By the time you request a ballot from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, prepare the papers, post the papers, give the members a chance to fill in their vote and to post the ballot papers back, and then count the ballot papers, you are looking at a couple of weeks at least. Then there would be the same lengthy time in order to end the industrial action as well, so you would see the dispute protracted far longer than necessary. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI was just having a discussion with a group of my colleagues in the office of the member for Aston and we were discussing this bill, the Workplace Relations Amendment (Secret Ballots for Protected Action) Bill 2002, as one does at the end of a long day. One of my colleagues alluded to matters of justice and democracy, and it reminded me of a most apposite quotation that I came across in some recent reading. It was actually by an American theologian, Reinhold Niebuhr, who wrote at the height of the Second World War in the publication Children of Light and Children of Darkness:

quote.para: Man's capacity for justice makes democracy possible, but man's inclination to injustice makes democracy necessary.

speech.para: This reflection is never truer than when applied to industrial democracy, for injustice is endemic in trade unionism. A number of members of this parliament have already related to the House some of the shocking evidence that has been given to the royal commission into the building and construction industry of violence, intimidation and corruption on the part of trade unions, particularly in my state of Western Australia. Members had the opportunity to consider this matter at length during the recent debate on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Prohibition of Compulsory Union Fees) Bill 2002. We have also had the opportunity to hear about the bloody factionalism within the manufacturing workers unions in Victoria. Yet the problem of union thuggery and violence goes beyond simply the politics of the present and the frustration that union officials obviously feel given the third failure of the ALP to reach the treasury bench and the growing threats to their influence within that organisation. Violence and intimidation and the standover as tactic lie at the heart of trade unionism itself. The threat of violence cannot be separated out from unionism; it is its very essence.

Since the very beginning of industrial militancy, violence has powered unionism as ideology, and that violence has been aimed not just at those persons taken to be the representatives of capital but at fellow workers who refuse to accept that ideology. Intimidation, coercion and violence are woven into the very fabric of the red flag. For too long in this country we have been inclined as citizens and as legislators to excuse violence that would be reviled in any circumstances other than in the workplace. It is to Australia's shame that the history of workplace relations in our country is littered with 100,000 examples of men and women subjected to harassment, intimidation, violence and genuine threats by thugs in trade union clothes. These crimes, whether petty or heinous, have been excused by the recourse to `social justice', the sacrifice of the individual to the mob: the conscientious objector stripped of his livelihood, his family terrified, his person harmed. Surely enough is enough! In this regard I could do no better than quote the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, who noted in a recent address to the Australian Industry Group in Canberra:

quote.para: ... the rule of law is the essence of a civilised society and the law must apply equally behind the factory gate as it applies in the street outside. This idea that something is not an offence because it takes place in the pursuit of an industrial dispute or because it has an ideological context is just wrong. Criminal behaviour is criminal behaviour. Breaking the law is reprehensible and it is always breaking the law, regardless of the context in which it takes place.

speech.para: The minister went on to say:

quote.para: The idea that industrial disputes are somehow different, that you can do things in an industrial dispute legitimately that you would never do in any other context, is wrong, and it is reminiscent of the old attitude that we used to have to domestic violenceâthat it somehow wasn't really violence. Well, thank God, we've grown past that. We need to do the same growing up when it comes to industrial law.

speech.para: Since 1996 this government has implemented reforms to set right those wrongs and to confront this crude Marxism. It was in that year that the public got an eyeful of the union violence before the doors of this very parliament. Aggrieved at the March election landslide against the Keating government, these thugsâdrunk on alcohol and ideologyârioted, trashed the forecourt and the building, terrified families and children, attacked the police and officers of this parliament and sought to intimidate the elected representatives of the Australian people. And the ALP winked like a criminal matriarch excusing the crimes of her children.

Nearly 12 months ago we saw the thugs of the CFMEU attack the former Minister for Defence at a Newcastle shipyard, smashing car windows and panels with wooden batons. These criminals had decided, in the words of their spokesman, Bob Cochrane, to give the minister `a bit of a send off'. The member for Forde will recall what a wonderful weekend 14 July was, when the Aston by-election took place.

talk.start.para: âHistory was made, again.
âHistory was made. On that weekend the Weekend Australian noted:

quote.para: The ugly scenes came on the eve of today's crucial by-election in the federal seat of Aston where Kim Beazley is trying to distance Labor from the alleged union violence in Melbourne.

speech.para: When asked why it had committed these acts of violence, the union claimed provocation. The then minister had provoked the violence by attempting to leave via a rear entrance to avoid their picket at the front. This action was, according to Mr Cochrane, `like a time bombâpeople just lost it'. This is the kind of inclination to injustice that necessitates genuine industrial democracy, and only the secret ballot can guarantee genuine industrial democracy. I do not have to go through the headlines of all of the news clippings: `Workers behaving badly', `Unions start to play hard ball', `Union behaviour embarrassing the ALP'âit goes on and on.

The Workplace Relations Amendment (Secret Ballots for Protected Action) Bill 2002 will guarantee the right to genuine democracy in the workplace and in turn will prevent unnecessary strikes. It will ensure the exercise of freedom of choice for workers and it will make unions and their officials accountable to their members. More importantly, the bill will shield from thuggish intimidation conscientious objectors to industrial action.

As members would be aware, Australia has made provision for secret ballots at the federal level of industrial relations for some time. However, such ballots have not been a precondition for the taking of industrial action. As the minister noted in his second reading speech on this bill, the Workplace Relations Act 1996âand industrial relations law more generallyâprovides protection against civil liability on the part of industrial action associated with workplace agreements. Given this legal privilege, it is entirely appropriate that a secret ballot of workers be conducted before a strike is launched.

This is not an onerous requirement. This is not the 1890s any more, regardless of the capacity of the opposition to live so comfortably in that imagined past. Secret ballots can be organised efficiently and with dispatch. This is not an unheard of requirement in an international context. Secret ballots in workplaces exist in the Republic of Ireland, Canada, Japan and Germany. They also exist in the United Kingdom and have done so for about 18 years. The British Labour government led by Tony Blair supports secret ballots and the British Trades Union Congress, the equivalent of the ACTU, has acknowledged the significant role of secret ballot provisions in ensuring proper industrial democracy.

The bill before the House follows bills passed by the House in 1999 and 2000 and will allow unions, or an individual employee who is a negotiating party, to make an application to the Industrial Relations Commission up to 30 days prior to the nominal expiry date of a current certified agreement, provided a bargaining period is in place. The IRC will then be required to make a determination on those applications within two working days. Where the application is made by a union, only the union members whose employment would be covered by the agreement in question would be entitled to participate in the ballot. In the case of employees seeking a non-union agreement, the vote will be available to all employees whose employment would be covered by the proposed agreement.

This bill allows for action to proceed where the ballot is successful and at least 40 per cent of those eligible to vote do so. The action may take place within 30 days after the declaration of the ballot or the agreement's nominal expiry date, whichever is the later. This represents a substantial change from the provisions of the 2000 bill. While the applicant may conduct the ballot with the significant financial assistance of the Commonwealth, it is necessary that the ballot be seen to be free and fair. As such, the bill does require that the IRC appoint an authorised independent adviser to oversee the process. Where complaints are raised about the conduct of a ballot and those complaints relate to matters that affect the ballot outcome and involve serious charges such as fraud, they will be investigated and justice upheld. Protection will also be afforded by the requirement that at the completion of the ballot both the authorised ballot agent and the independent adviser will forward to the industrial registrar a written report.

This bill is good law. It addresses a need and it corrects an injustice. It implements a policy initiative twice endorsed by the Australian people at federal elections. It deserves the support of all members of this House, not just the government. It is fundamental to our notions of democracy and justice and, while it deserves the support of all members of this House and the government, it should also be afforded passage through the upper house. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âI wish to draw the attention of the House to a most exciting plan to provide Launceston and north-eastern Tasmania with a state-of-the-art aquatic centre. The aim is to provide a multipurpose leisure centre that meets the needs of a broad range of people from across the region in the areas of recreation, health, fitness and competitive sport at the club level. Its focus will be on providing leisure and recreation opportunities, complementing but not competing with the Hobart Aquatic Centre.

speech.para: The health and wellbeing of Australians should be a major priority of every government, whether it be at the local, state or Commonwealth level. There has never been a shortage of evidence that a healthy and fit population significantly reduces the pressure on the public purse. I become increasingly concerned for the future of both the nation and its individual citizens every time I hear or read of increasing rates of obesity in children, declining participation rates in sport and recreation, and the threat to leisure activities because of public liability insurance and the like.

talk.start.para: âHear, hear!

âI welcome the member for Braddon, who I know supports this as well. In my electorate of Bass and the greater northern region of Tasmania there is an additional need for appropriate aquatic facilities, especially those facilities that provide for the acquisition of water skills. The whole of our region has no point of land which is more than 80 kilometres from the sea and it also contains a large number of rivers, lakes and other watercourses. Learn to swim campaigns, the acquisition of lifesaving skills and the opportunity for people to maintain these skills have always been an important feature of the life education of most Tasmanians. We, as representatives of the people, must be proactive in ensuring that every community has reasonable access to appropriate sport, recreation and leisure facilities. Alternatively, when a community makes a reasonable proposition, we should look to provide it with all reasonable support.

speech.para: In 2001, the Launceston City Council completed a comprehensive business plan comparing four different facility options, utilising a steering committee of state government and community representation. In August the council determined that it would seek to build a new indoor aquatic centre in Launceston within five years, adopting a regional model as the preferred option. The estimated capital budget was $17.2 million, based on October 2000 dollars, plus $750,000 in fit-out costs. The council resolved to commit $8 million towards the project, subject to securing regional support and a multilateral funding agreement with all levels of government.

In late 2001, the Northern Tasmanian Municipal Organisation, a cooperative comprising all local government bodies in the northern region of the state, requested its recreation committee, with assistance from the state office of sport and recreation, to produce a regional aquatic strategy. The completed strategy calls for a hierarchy of facilities, including a regional centre in Launceston complemented by district facilities at Deloraine, Scottsdale, George Town and St Helens and supplemented by local community facilities. In December 2001, the Northern Tasmanian Municipal Organisation ratified the strategy, indicating the breadth of community support for the centre and the approach to be taken to the project. In April of this year the state government matched the council's allocation to the project of $8 million, on the proviso that the federal government matched the commitment also. The Launceston City Council is currently preparing a development plan for its preferred site for the aquatic centre, seeking to consolidate and integrate several key sporting facilities into a major sporting and recreation precinct for the city and the region. This will maximise both the social and economic benefits of the investment for the northern Tasmanian community.

There are many reasons apart from the ones I have already mentioned as to why this admirable proposal should be given the green light. The latest research undertaken by the NTMO Recreation Committee at the end of 2001 indicated that 65 to 85 per cent of Greater Launceston residents would potentially use the new centre. Whilst swimming is one of the top three recreational pursuits in Tasmania behind walking and fishing, the regional aquatic strategy report indicates clearly that swimming participation in the north is declining, owing to a poor standard of facilities and a lack of access to appropriate facilities. Of the 11 remaining council pools, eight are more than 35 years old and none is open in winter. The result is particularly dramatic in the case of older adults, with the lack of a heated indoor water space resulting in one of the lowest participation rates by older adults in water recreation and therapy in Australia. Access for people with disabilities or mobility problems and for those requiring accident rehabilitation is also severely limited. The poor quality of pools in northern Tasmania is impacting on the standard of swimming being attained by northern school students. According to statistics from the education department, only 40 per cent of primary students attain the national benchmark by the time they finish the water safety program. I commend this fine proposal to the House and urge the government to join with the Launceston City Council and the Tasmanian state government in making this wonderful new facility a reality.

subdebateinfo.title: Road Safety: Seatbelts on School Buses

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to do something fairly unusual, but my colleagues will know that I am the sort of person who gives credit where credit is due. Tonight I want to thank the Queensland Labor government for their decision to implement a trial of seatbelts in school buses, as they announced in their budget this week. I see this as a step in the right direction. It is only one small step, but it is still better than the stonewalling we have had to date. Members may recall that last year I presented in the parliament a private member's motion calling for the state government to legislate for the compulsory fitting of seatbelts in all new buses. I canvassed the many safety reasons that we have compulsory fitting of seatbelts on all long-distance coaches. It really makes you wonder why we still leave the most precious cargo of allâour schoolchildrenâunprotected.

speech.para: I have had an enormous amount of support from the community on this issue, with more than 500 local residents signing a petition to the state government. I am very fortunate to have two remarkable women in my electorate, Kim Bax and Kim Limberg, who have been tireless campaigners for school bus safety and the fitting of seatbelts on school buses. Kim and Kim came to Canberra at their own expense and met with many advisers when I moved my private member's motion last year. I congratulate, thank and pay tribute to them for their ongoing efforts. They are truly community-minded people who believe wholeheartedly in the issue and want to ensure that children in the future can travel to school more safely. That the Queensland government has agreed to implement a trial of seatbelts is largely due to the untiring efforts of the `two Kims', as they are known throughout the district. I know they will keep up the fight and I look forward to continuing to work with them.

It looks like we will have our work cut out for us for, although the state government has agreed to a trial of seatbelts on 10 school buses, there was another initiative announced in the budget that has me a little puzzled. The state government has earmarked $16.7 million for a scheme to replace old school buses on non-urban routes over the next four years. On the face of it, that is a very positive measure, and I welcome it. But there is a catch: there is no requirement for these new buses to be fitted with seatbelts. I certainly hope that the state government is planning to examine the results of a properly conducted seatbelt trial, involving schoolchildren of all agesânot just children of high school ageâbefore it goes ahead and spends that much money on replacing old buses with new ones that are still not fitted with seatbelts.

It seems ridiculous that the Queensland government would want to buy new buses that are not fitted with seatbelts, especially when the New South Wales minister is apparently proposing to call for the fitting of seatbelts in all new school buses at the next Australian transport ministers conference. There is a huge amount of research that points to the value of seatbelts on buses. I would hope that the results of a trial would be properly examined before new buses are purchased.

If commonsense prevails, the next step will be to at least legislate for all new replacement school buses to be fitted with seatbelts. This would surely be the focus of the state government's replacement scheme over the next four years. I think Kim Limberg was absolutely right when she said recently:

quote.para: You would think the smart state would be the first to implement seatbelts on new buses, not sit back and wait for another state to introduce them first.

speech.para: I call on Mr Beattie to ensure that the seatbelt trial is not just a stunt and that the Queensland government does not waste close to $17 million buying new school buses that are not fitted with seatbelts. I am hopeful that commonsense will prevail. Let us make sure that these positive steps in the right direction are followed through so that we do not have to continue to debate this issue over the next 10 years. It simply makes sense to ensure that all new school buses are fitted with seatbelts. Anything less is continuing to compromise the safety of our children.

In the few minutes remaining, I would like to also congratulate a very special lady in my electorate, Delaune Pollard. She is coping with many personal challenges of her own, but she has taken the time to launch a book titled Midlife challenge. It was launched by the Minister for Ageing, Kevin Andrews, last week in my electorate. It is a book about understanding and coping with the decline in thinking and behaviour in ageing persons. Delaune wrote:

quote.para: Like me, so many of my friends and colleagues now in their middle age have experienced or are experiencing emotional turmoil as they add another significant responsibility to their already busy and committed lives.

speech.para: That responsibility is assisting and caring for aged relatives. She goes on to say:

quote.para: For me, taking on this role coincided with a series of crises in my lifeâ

speech.para: This left her very vulnerable and fragile. As an occupational therapist and studying cognate therapy, she wrote about her experiences, which took her a fair amount of time. It is the most commonsense book that I have ever read. I would like to conclude by congratulating Delaune Pollard and recommending her book. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe member for Forde is to be congratulated for her work, and the Queensland government, on seatbelts in school buses. I was happy to second that motion in this House some time last year, if I remember correctly. It is great to see some young people in the gallery tonight. I welcome them. It is very interesting that the member for Forde brought up the issue of safety for young people, because that is the very issue that I want to talk about. Last time we were in this House, I mentioned that my son would be turning 16 next Wednesday. That is great news, but the other news is that he is going for his learner's licence. That brought to my attention the whole question of novice drivers and their record on our roads.

speech.para: I love young people, but unfortunately the statistics show that young people are very prone to accidents on the road, particularly in relation to their driving skills and speed. I will share the statistics with my son when I see him for two days over the weekend, but I would also like to share them with the House tonight. These statistics are in light of my earlier comments on the lax advertising standards in terms of the code for road safety. I would like to acknowledge the very positive work of Senator Boswell in trying to tighten the guidelines on advertisers' use of speed in vehicle ads.

Between 1995 and 1999 in Tasmania, my home state, novice driversâthat is, drivers between the years of 17 and 19âmade up nearly seven per cent of road fatalities and injuries and, together with their passengers, made up 11.6 per cent of the road toll. In all, 19 per cent of the road toll involved novice drivers. Drivers aged less than 25 years made up 39 per cent of the overall road toll. Statistically, novice drivers are overrepresented, unfortunately, in road crashes. In 1995 to 1999 they comprised 12.6 per cent of all drivers in casualty crashes but only accounted for four per cent of the population, 3.8 per cent of all licence holders and 1.7 per cent of all the kilometres travelled.

Data indicates that novice driver crashes were very similar to the crash patterns of mature driversâwe age them between 25 years and 64 yearsâbut they were more likely to have been judged as follows: responsible for their crashes, 68 per cent compared to 31.9 per cent of mature drivers; involved in crashes attributed to inexperience, 13.4 per cent as opposed to 1.8 per cent; and speeding, 10.4 per cent compared to 6.7 per cent. They were more likely to have been judged to have been involved in crashes late on Fridays and Saturdays and early on Saturdays and Sundaysâ18.6 per cent compared to 9.4 per cent. The fact is that they are out and about. They are having a good time, but unfortunately the statistics in terms of casualties are very disturbing. They are more likely to be in single-vehicle crashesâ36.3 per cent compared to 25.4 per cent. Those involving collisions with roadside furnitureâthat is an interesting phraseâand overturning is 32 per cent compared to 19.8 per cent of mature drivers, and carrying passengers at the time, statistically 50 per cent compared to 36 per cent. Over two-thirds of novice drivers had their crashes in a 60-kilometre-per-hour speed zone. Unfortunately, like the mature driver cohort, the majority of drivers involved in casualty crashes were malesâ63 per cent for the novice drivers and 60 per cent for mature drivers. Why is this so in our community?

Clearly we have to do everything we can to make motoring safe and enjoyable for all drivers. However, for everyone involved it should be safety first and enjoyment second, and not the other way round. I am not sure this is the message, however, if we take vehicle advertisements literally. To see an ad that depicts as funny a driver speeding down his home driveway, between objects, including toys, with his child laughing gleefully at him, when we have the highest casualty rates off roadsâthat is, in drivewaysâin the world, tells us a lot about what our community says about its standards. I hope that code changes and very quickly, because I want my son to come home every night when he has been out driving.

talk.start.para: âAlong with you, Mr Speaker, and the member for Braddon, I would like to welcome the 65 students from the heartland of Corangamite. They come from the primary schools of Meredith, Lethbridge, Anakie, Inverleigh and Teesdale. It is the biggest adjournment speech audience that we have had in the 40th Parliament, and they have come all the way from Corangamite to be here. They have observed you in action today, Mr Speaker, during question time. They were perfectly well behaved in the gallery. They did not speak, and they did not misbehave like some members of the parliament do!

speech.para: They saw the Treasurer, the Hon. Peter Costello, defend quite vigorously the government on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. It is a very important policy position where a copayment is being proposed to increase the cost of prescriptions from $3.60 to $4.60, and after 52 scripts, as these young people understand, pharmaceuticals will be free. The students reported to me that the proceedings were lively. They also suggested that you did have control of the proceedings at most times!

If they had been here earlier this week, they would have heard a report from the Prime Minister on his visit to America, where he met President Bush, Vice President Cheney and most other senior leaders of the US administration. They would have heard the Prime Minister talk about the US farm bill and its impact on the farmers of Meredith and Corangamite. There was also the Prime Minister's observation that undue influence in the US Senate, with two senators per state from the Midwest, made sure that the US farm bill, which is so detrimental to the farmers of Corangamite and Australia in general, was passedâvery much to the disadvantage of all Australians. The Prime Minister also spoke to the US House of Representatives on behalf of all Australians, and that great honour of speaking to the House of Representatives is not bestowed on many leaders.

Those young students in the gallery had their own parliament back in Meredith. They had a debate on the topic `Homework was essential'. On that occasion, Brigitte Gargan from Meredith was elected as the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition was John Collins from Inverleigh. They had a very interesting debate, and they spoke well. They behaved well under Speaker McArthur, who kept control of the gathering, and no member was suspended! You will be interested to know, Mr Speaker, that the government won the vote with 31 votes compared with the opposition's 30 votes.

Those young students come from Corangamite, as I said, where their parents run wool and cropping, globulus gum tree operations, cattle and fat lambs. In the last year or so, times have been prosperous around Meredith, Teesdale and Inverleigh. We have had good rains and good prices. These schools are located in the Golden Plains Shire. It is the second fastest growing shire in Victoria. It is south of Ballarat and Bannockburn. The lifestyle is excellent, and people like to come and live in the Golden Plains Shire. The Teesdale school is a mud-brick school. It is environmentally friendly and the heating is particularly good. It is a very good little school, and I have been there. At Anakie, they have one of the best wine regions in Australia. It is much better than the Barossa Valley, where the Speaker comes from!

talk.start.para: âOrder!
âThe wine from Anakie is much better! I would just like to draw the attention of the House to that.

speech.para: Inverleigh school is a little bluestone school, which has had some improvements. It started in 1874 on the Hamilton Highway. Lethbridge is the centre and the focus of the Golden Plains Shire, and we are hoping to get a new school there in the very near future. Meredith is the home of the former premier Sir Henry Bolte, who was the Premier of Victoria for 17 years from 1955 to 1972. My close friend Mr Tom Austin, who died last week, was also born at Meredith. He was a cabinet minister in the Hamer and Thompson governments and was a confidant of Premier Kennett. When he died, his daughter said that he wanted to come back in the next life as a black duck and fly over my property at Meningoort at Camperdown because he knew that I was such a bad shot that he could fly for evermore!

We welcome our young students here to Canberra. They have seen the parliament in action and democracy at work. It has been a vigorous and open debate. We may have a premier and a prime minister amongst those young people. We wish them well and we are delighted they are here. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI join the member for Corangamite in welcoming the students from Corangamite. They are fortunate to have the opportunity to hear not only the member for Corangamite but also the members for Forde and, I suspect, Canning, Bass, Stirling and Braddon.

âMr Speaker, as you are aware, there was a rally outside the House today attended by people with disabilities, their carers and family members, and workers from the disability field and other community groups. They were here because of their concerns about the government's intention with the budget to change the criteria for the disability support pension by reducing the work hours from 30 hours to 15 hours, which means, if the government goes ahead with this, that many people will lose their pensions. As well, they wanted to express their concern over the government's intention in relation to the PBS to increase the copayment by $1.

speech.para: I would like to take this opportunity to read to the House a letter from one of my constituents. Mrs Willy Fisher is the mother of Jodi Fisher, whose family featured in a front page story in the West Australian newspaper on 22 May 2002 entitled `Pensioner family bear brunt of Budget'. The article outlines the fact that the Fishers will be $180 per fortnight poorer under the government's proposed policy to change the criteria for the disability support pension. They will lose more than $1,000 a year in cancelled disability concessions, leaving them in total $6,000 poorer a year. I read with disgust some of the letters to the editor in the days following this article. This reaction shows an ugly side of the Australian character. It highlights the success of this government's campaign of wedge politics to victimise the less well off in our country. I would like to read to the House the letter that I received from Mrs Willy Fisher, who is Jodi's concerned mother. She says:

quote.para: Dear Jann,

My name is Willy Fisher and I am asking for your help. The girl Jodi Fisher, on the front page of the West Australian (22/5/02), is our daughter. We've been through a terrible few days with her as she is extremely worried about how the Commonwealth budget will affect her family. Her husband received brain injuries in a major car accident nine years ago, prior to their marriage. Since then he and my daughter have contended with months of in and out patient hospital treatment, years of rehabilitation and difficult often failed attempts at re-entering the workplace.

He now manages to work 22 hours a week in a supported position, which was found for him by a disability support service. Even this is very difficult for him. He struggles every day and is not capable of working any more hours per week than he is already. As it is, each day requires ten times the efforts of an âableâ person. My daughter and her husband have not slept or eaten properly for days and I am extremely concerned for their wellbeing. It is horrible that this is being done to the most vulnerable people in society. My daughter does not know how they will survive from day to day. They do not drink or smoke, live quite simply, have two fourteen year old cars, hardly go out and do not know where they will be able to cut costs.

Their fears grow daily as they know this will only become more difficult as the children get older. I wonder if you would take this matter to parliament so that we can be assured that someone is fighting for our cause and the cause of many others in similar situations, some of whom are probably still ignorant of the full extent to which these changes could affect them. These people are not bludgers or welfare cheats. They are doing the best they can in extremely difficult circumstances.
Hoping you will be able to help us.
Yours sincerely
Willy Fisher.

speech.para: Mrs Fisher gives a heartfelt account of the problems facing her family. I want to contrast this with a letter from the letters page of the West Australian of 24 May 2002 by Margaret Schofield of Willeton. The letter is entitled `No sympathy for this family' and it includes the words:

quote.para: Every picture tells a story. This clearly is not a deprived family. Apart from the enormous advantage of owning their own home at an early age, one partner has the personal resources, if she so chooses to do so, to earn a good living in a profession where employment is plentiful. Hard working taxpayers struggling to make ends meet must be gnashing their teeth after reading the financial set up of this âpensioner familyâ and their protestations of unfair treatment.

speech.para: The questions are: did the Fishers choose to have the traffic accident which left Mr Fisher permanently disabled? No. Did Mr Fisher choose not to work and lie around feeling sorry for himself instead of trying to make a contribution to society through working? No. Did Mrs Fisher do wrong by sacrificing her career and staying at home to raise her children like hundreds of thousands of other mothers? Did she have a choice, when her husband is physically unable to look after their children at home? No.

The level of castigation from ignorant and judgmental people like Mrs Schofield continues with some comments made by Mike Larry of Kalamunda. I will not read them out, but can I say that we have a society that talks about justice, equity and fairness and we have a society that considers itself to be compassionate. But, from what I have read out, people like Mrs Schofield and Mr Larry should be ashamed of themselves. They should be ashamed for attacking a family based on the number of children's toys in the photograph. They should be ashamed for presuming the couple own their own home. Like them, and most Australians, the banks own the Fishers' home. Mr Larry should be ashamed that he contradicts himself in his letter saying that he works and studies full time. It is difficult to do both full time. He should be ashamed about his statement claiming that he gets no government support. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Canning Electorate: Brookdale Liquid Waste Treatment Facility

talk.start.para: âI would like to raise the issue of the Brookdale Liquid Waste Treatment Facility in my electorate. The Brookdale waste treatment plant is a toxic waste dump in Forrestdale and it is a sad fact that this plant has been operating for some time. After much agitation, community involvement and many rallies in the electorate, the community were able to get to the point where they almost railroaded the state Labor government into taking measures to eventually close it down. The problem is that this waste treatment facility receives PCBs, inflammable liquids and even radioactive waste. It is a shocking indictment on the waste treatment facilities in Western Australia that in the middle of a residential area we could have a toxic waste dump like this. The state Department of Environmental Protection are a disgraceful organisation in that, when this matter was first raised some time last year, they even denied that toxic waste was being dumped into this facility. They denied the fact that contaminants were getting into the water table and that the level of contaminants was causing health problems in the electorate. It was not until greater analysis had been made of this siteâcarried out because of public pressure and because workers began to tell members of the public what was actually going into the siteâthat this issue was brought to a head.

speech.para: To her credit, the local state member Alannah MacTiernan took the matter from a very weak state environment minister, in the form of Judy Edwards, and saw that something was done about this. She took measures to stop waste of that nature being received in this facility. But I have to inform the House this evening that that is not happening the way it was meant to. I am informed today, for example, that many toxic wastesâPCBs and those sorts of contaminantsâare still being sneaked into the waste treatment facility via septic trucks. In other words, the sewage trucks that come into this facility are now being laced with highly toxic inflammable waste. I am told that in some cases chemicals are put inside these trucks so that they cannot be identified. This is a terrible indictment of the waste treatment facilities in Western Australia, as I have already said.

But the greatest indictment here is of the Department of Environmental Protection because they have been very slow in addressing this matter. They should be more proactive in closing this place down. The deal was that by the end of February these materials would not be allowed to be received into this facility. In the electorate there are a number of concerned groups, groups such as Forrestdale Action Group and Mothers and Others, a group of breastfeeding mothers who are very concerned about this sort of waste in their neighbourhood in my electorate. I have just got off the phone from one of the people involved in this matter, who told me that this material is still being received.

The DEPâand this is a fault of the state governmentâhad $5 million cut from their budget in the recent state budget in Western Australia, so their ability to do the job is being hamstrung in some respects. We now have the situation where people in this area have contaminated water bores. They are suffering ill health and are experiencing skin irritations, loss of hair, and breathing problems which complicate the condition of anyone with asthma et cetera. The facility is causing a great number of health problems. There needs to be an audit of the health problems in the electorate that have been caused by this toxic facility. There is going to be a rally on 29 March in Canning in Waterfall Road in the Forrestdale area, to deal with this matter. I encourage anybody that wants to involve themselvesâand I will certainly be alerting the electorate to thisâin making sure that the government and the Department of Environmental Protection do their job by closing this facility down once and for all and by having this material treated in the right place to do so straightaway.

subdebateinfo.title: Aviation: Hoxton Park and Bankstown Airports

talk.start.para: âHoxton Park Airport is located on the south-western boundary of the Fowler electorate. It is a small general aviation airport but one of the busiest airports in Australia, with over 120,000 movements each year. Hoxton Park is used mainly for flight training by single-engined aircraft and small helicopters. Despite the number of movements, Hoxton Park does not have a control tower and has a questionable safety record. In 1998 the pilot and passenger of a small aircraft died following a mid-air collision as they entered the landing pattern at Hoxton Park. Wreckage from the aircraft crashed into a home in Hinchinbrook, fortunately not causing further loss of life. In 1999 the pilot of a light aircraft died when a second aircraft landed on top of him as he prepared to take off from Hoxton Park Airport. In 2000 a vintage aircraft crashed on approach to Hoxton Park when attempting a forced landing, and last year a twin-engine aircraft crashed on approach to Hoxton Park Airport, seriously injuring the pilot. There have been more incidents since then.

speech.para: When you consider that Hoxton Park Airport is surrounded by residential areas, at least one serious or fatal crash each year is a worrying thought. And there is further development planned. This year residential land to the west of the airport is scheduled for release and construction is due to start on the Western Sydney Orbital. This important transport link is planned to run across the flight path at the southern end of the runway and then parallel to the runway at a distance of less than 100 metres. The environmental impact statement for the Western Sydney Orbital noted that the road would affect flight operations at Hoxton Park. The statement recommended height restrictions for the Cowpasture Road overbridge, precautions for high trucks using the road and roadside lighting limitations.

At the other end of the Fowler electorate is Bankstown Airport, which is Australia's busiest airport with over 400,000 movements each year. It is planned to be sold as a package along with Hoxton Park Airport and Camden Airport. We know that the government wants the prospective buyer of Bankstown Airport to expand its use for passenger jets. This would displace training and other flights at Bankstown and lead to greater use of Hoxton Park Airport. Any increase in air traffic at Hoxton Park can only impact on its already suspect safety record. Hoxton Park Airport should not be sold to a private operator unless a full public review of its operations is carried out and nearby residents can be assured of its safetyâthat is most importantâand, if not, it should be closed down.

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
Dr STONE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âI wish to put on record the heroic struggle of a lot of the small towns in my electorate of Murray. In particular, we received the cruel news in the first week of April that the National Australia Bank is leaving town. We have had a history of the contraction of smaller towns across Australia dating back to the earliest times when they went from horse and buggy to motor vehicle transportation systems. The First World War knocked out a total generation in terms of small communities surviving into the 1930s. But when you lose your only bank in a small town it really can mean a death knell. A lot of the local businesses that take cashâhotels, garages and shops of any descriptionâneed to lodge their cash, ideally at the end of each business day. They do not have the insurance or the security facilities to hold that cash over a week or longer. You also have the older members of the population and women with children who like to be able to access a bank where there is a human being across the counter and where they can get out of the cold rather than stand on a blustery corner trying to access an automated teller machine. A small town that does not have a bank is a place where you see streams of cars at the end of the working day leaving to go to the next larger regional centre to shop, to do their banking and to go to other services.

speech.para: So when the National Australia Bank announced on 3 April that they were to take another swipe at their local branches and they were to close Pyramid Hill, Tongala, Rushworth and Stanhope banks, a chill went through those communities. I want to put on record, though, the fact that each of those communities is fighting back. They now have in process the development of rural transaction centres. These are an excellent new strategy that this Commonwealth government under John Howard's leadership has put in place, where a combination of a range of important Commonwealth and other services are put together in a building that may have been empty for some time or may even be a converted domestic dwelling. Rural transaction centres are now well on the way through the very hard work of the community groups themselves, particularly in Stanhope, Tongala, Dookie, Leitchville, Rushworth and Pyramid Hill.

I want to commend the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Wilson Tuckey, who is personally engaged in making sure the towns hardest hit by the withdrawal of banks like the National Australia Bank do not, in fact, have an even speedier decline but have a new era based on their own community struggle to make good. I think the National Australia Bank should be condemned. It was only a week later that they announced some of the greatest profits on record, having just informed these towns that they could no longer see themselves clear to service them, on the basis of declining rural business through their doors.

talk.start.para: âI take this opportunity to place on record the community's appreciation for the work of the Wesley Church Community Centre in Wollongong which caters for the needs of a growing number of homeless people in my electorate and to recognise the growing number of homeless people in Australia as a whole. The Wesley Church Community Centre was originally put into operation on the basis that it would cater for about 50 people, on average, a day. That list has now grown to approximately 166 people attending and eating at the community centre on a daily basis.

speech.para: A recent article in our local paper drew my attention to the plight of homeless people. I guess that for many homelessness is not something that we contend with or see on a regular basis. I think the stereotype of homelessness has always been depicted around an older man, usually with alcohol or drug problems, living on the streets. But a recent research study undertaken by Mission Australia actually debunks the stereotype that we have all grown to believe is associated with homelessness. It was interesting that the average Australian, like me, underestimates the magnitude of the problem. In the research study undertaken by Mission Australia, half of all the people who responded believed that there were fewer than 10,000 people homeless on any given night in Australia. The actual facts are quite alarming. As the research study indicates, there are over 105,000 people on any one night who are homeless. By homeless, they mean someone who does not have a stable and secure home to live in. Of course, a large number of these are described as `sleeping rough'âthat is the people that we see on park benches and sheltering under cardboard boxes. Large numbers live in boarding homes and large numbers are accommodated in government provided SAAP accommodation. Others are described as `sofa surfing'.

The Wesley Church Community Centre is like many not-for-profit organisations in my electorate that cater for the most dispossessed and disadvantaged people. I think it is incumbent on this government to pay these organisations the money that is outstanding for their award increases, to resource the sector more generously to cope with unmet demand and to remove the threats to disability funding that are still hanging over many organisations' heads. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise today to draw the House's attention to the state of the sugar industry in Queensland. It is on the brink of total collapse as a result of four consecutive years of low world sugar prices, poor weather and crop disease. An American sugar farmer receives, courtesy of American taxpayers, US19c per poundâsugar producers in the European Union are similarly protected and cossetedâwhile an Australian sugarcane farmer receives the world price of less than 6c per pound, which is well below the cost of production. Hard-pressed Australian cane farmers have to accept that the subsidies paid to US farmers and others depress world sugar prices by 17 per cent and strip $US1.5 billion out of the income of sugar exporters such as Australia.

speech.para: The question is often asked: are Australian cane farmers efficient and productive? Yes, they are. They produce 25 tonnes per hectare more than their nearest competitive rival. Are they subsidised? No, they are not. The Australian cane industry regrettably has become the canary in the coalmine of globalisation. Because 92 per cent of raw sugar from Queensland is exported onto the corrupt world market, they are the first industry to demonstrate the signs of that corrupt world market. Pressure is building up on the beef and dairy industries as well as the sugar industry. There is much that the industry can and will do to become profitable and sustainable in the long term, although its comparative advantage is being overrun by subsidies to and devaluations in the currency of its competitors. What the industry needs is a short-term financial bridge to be able to reach a profitable end point. I am confident that the government will continue to listen sympathetically to the plight of farmers and to act decisively to assist them.

I have to acknowledge that the Liberal-National government in the last parliament gave some $63 million worth of assistance to over 5,000 recipients through the sugar assistance package. That was very well received. As well, the Prime Minister listened very sympathetically, prior to his trip to the United States, and raised the issue of the sugar industry with the US government. That is very much appreciated and his keeping faith with the sugar industry has resonated with all growers. It is time for a new paradigm for Australian agriculture in the rural and regional communities that depend on it. Agricultural experts have to shed some long-heldâbut flawedâbeliefs that deregulation is good, that small farms are necessarily inefficient, and that increasing economies of scale will overcome all problems; that is simply not the case. There has to be a plan for long-term profitability so that farmers who are efficient are able to be profitable, regardless of world prices and weather conditions, and that there has to be a bridge to enable them to reach that end point. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am delighted to rise today to share with the parliament my pride in the public schools of Newcastle. Although I have always been one to champion the achievements of our local students, teachers, staff and school communities, last week was a very special one for public education in my electorate. Last week more than 3,000 primary and secondary students from 115 government schools throughout the Hunter, Manning and Central Coast regions performed in the 10th annual production of Star Struck, a three-hour spectacular of live music, dance, movement and drama. With ticket sales of almost 18,000, the 10th birthday celebration of Star Struck was a huge success delighting audiences of proud family members and the general public.

speech.para: Every year the most striking feature of the Star Struck performance is that thousands of students of all ages, circumstances and talents are polished into stars and entertainers by the dedicated production team of directors, choreographers, costume set and props designers, musicians, and stage and technical managers. Who are those clever professionals? They are the teachers and students from our public schools who willingly devote many, many hours above and beyond their normal duties and tasks to make sure that the show goes on.
