While it is disappointing that a doctor has not yet been found for Karuah, I will continue to push the issue and help any interested doctors in any way I can. Council has agreed, however, to push the state government to set up a polyclinic in Medowie.

I also bring to the minister's attention the statements by Bob Carr and Andrew Refshauge in the lead-up to the 1995 state elections in New South Wales, and those comments were to the effect that if they did not reduce the waiting lists in New South Wales in the first 12 months they would resign. That message was heard loud and clear by the people in the Paterson area. It was heard and believed, and they voted in support of the Labor Party. But, guess what? Seven years down the track the waiting lists have blown out, and that has had a serious effect on my constituents. What is even more alarming is that this blow-out has hit maximum levels in regional areas. Whilst they have made some feeble attempts in the cities they have ignored, to a large extent, the people in the regional areas.

I call on the minister to bring Bob Carr and his cabinet to account for their lack of spending in regional areas in New South Wales, particularly in the Port Stephens area, to bring doctors there so that in the Forster-Tuncurry region we could establish a polyclinic. They have even refused to negotiate with the community owned Cape Hawk Hospital to lease private beds. They have refused to provide any support whatsoever. Why? Because quite simply they are a citycentric government. Minister, I pay you due credit: you have looked beyond the cities and you have looked at providing support in regional areas, but I say to you clearly, while that is nice we need more, but we also need you to bring Bob Carr to account.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr ANDREWS
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member for Paterson for his remarks and indicate to him that from the Commonwealth government's perspective it is important that state governments right around Australia meet their commitments to provide hospital and medical services which are primarily, particularly in terms of hospital services, the responsibility of state governments. I can say to him that the coalition is committed to Australians having access to quality health care. As he might know, through the regional health strategy, the coalition has increased the number of doctors practising in rural and regional Australia. Since 1999, when the general practice memorandum of understanding was signed, which includes the Division of General Practice, the Royal Australian College of GPs and the Rural Doctors Association, the Medicare rebate for standard consultation has increased by over 14 per cent and by over 20 per cent for longer consultations. The 2001 budget, as he might recall, contained a $750 million boost to Medicare to allow doctors to offer better care for patients affected by asthma, diabetes, mental illness and cervical cancer and to allow rural GPs to employ more clinical nurses. This funding also included a specific amount of $300 million to fund longer GP consultations under Medicare.

speech.para: The government has also allocated a further $236 million over four years for the Practice Incentives Program. This program should encourage doctors to continue to bulk-bill their clients. There has been a substantial increase in the number of GPs practising in rural and remote Australia. The number of GPs billing Medicare from these areas has increased by over 11 per cent since 1997 from 5,706 to 6,363 by the year 2000. This is a matter which the coalition will remain concerned about and we will make whatever efforts are necessary to ensure that our commitment to rural Australia and that of the state governments remains.

talk.start.para: âI want to talk about an issue relating to the availability of appropriate prophylaxis for haemophiliacsâthat is, the availability of Recombinant Factor VIII. I have a constituent in my electorate who has three sons who are haemophiliacs. The two oldest sons have got hepatitis C as a result of having to rely in their earlier years on Plasma Factor VIII for their prophylaxis. The third son has always had available to him Recombinant Factor VIII and has no blood diseases as a result. The second son has been on a program of Interferon and Ribavirin for some time and has in fact changed his hepatitis C status from hepatitis C positive to hepatitis C negative, which is wonderful. The current criterion, as we understand it, is that had he never had a blood-borne disease he would have Recombinant Factor VIII available to him. What I want to find out is, if he has moved his hepatitis C status to hepatitis C negative, would it be possible to have made available to him Recombinant Factor VIII so that he is not exposed to future risks of new blood-borne diseases?

speech.para: The other issue that I want to raise is the commercial arrangements between the government and CSL for the provision of Factor VIII. Recombinant Factor VIII is an expensive product and it has been in very short supply, hence these quite logical rules to make sure that it is used where it will have the most benefit. I would like some kind of an update as to what is happening with the relative cost factors of plasma Factor VIII and recombinant Factor VIII and whether, in fact, we are getting to a situation where recombinant Factor VIII might be more generally available. Is there anything in the commercial arrangements which is encouraging CSL for commercial reasons to want to encourage the continued use of plasma Factor VIII when recombinant Factor VIII might in fact now be an affordable product?

I am also interested to know where the situation is at with regard to people who have bleeding disorders when they are likely to be having surgery and may need some kind of prophylaxis as part of that interventionâfor example, a patient with thrombocytopenia who has a need for an urgent medical procedure and has not been able to store their own blood in case anything goes wrong during the operation. Is that patient being forced to rely on plasma Factor VIII in those surgical procedures, with the attendant risk of their contracting some as yet unknown blood-borne disease or would it be possible to make generally available recombinant Factor VIII to mitigate that risk?

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr ANDREWS
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: âI understand the nature of the questions that the honourable member for Kingston is asking. I should indicate to him that I do not have the answers here and now but I undertake to provide him with the answers in due course.

âI take this opportunity to make some general observations about the changes that were proposed by this year's budget to the PBS and to raise at a later stage some more specific issues. I think that one of the real problems about the changes that were proposed by the budget to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme is that they have been done in isolation outside of a proper look at the way in which the PBS operates within the whole health care system. To increase the cost of drugs by 28 per centâespecially in the instance of concessional patients, but also for general patientsâis a large impost. The fact that it comes out in a budget rather clouds proper discussion of the issues. Perhaps it is time to review the way in which the PBS has operated.

speech.para: Nobody would question that the PBS has been very successful in meeting the aims that were set for the PBS well over 50 years ago when it first started. It does ensure that there is universal access to drugs at a proper price for the Australian population. Now, as we see the government tinkering with the way in which the copayments relate to the overall cost, it is perhaps time to revisit a number of the factors that impinge upon the PBS. Of course, one of the things that has been said in the budget papers is that the increase of 28 per cent in the copayment `will restore to previous levels the balance between the contribution to the cost of drugs by consumers and the government'.

One could logically take from that statement that that will continue to be the case and that we will see increases in the copayment that go well beyond indexation, if in fact one of the problems is that higher cost drugs are coming on to the PBS. But I think we have to look at what is going to be the outcome of those increased costsâwhat will change in the way people perceive their ability to access these drugs, the way they see their ability to afford them and the way they will make decisions about whether they actually have their prescriptions dispensed.

As has been stated on behalf of the opposition, we have no problems with a number of the items in the budget that go to trying to effect change on things that place pressure on the PBS. But many of these things are not new. If one looks at the budget documents, one has to ask what is now going to be the magic solution to a number of these things. For instance, when we talk about sitting down with the manufacturers of generic drugs and negotiating prices, and about a new computer system that will in some way make it even harder for doctors to not prescribe the lower cost drugs, we have been trying to do this for years.

When I make some of these comments, I acknowledge that we have had governments from both sides of the chamber in charge of trying to combat a number of these pressures that are on the PBS. But, simply put, when we look at what is proposed here in the budget, in the isolation of just being budget measures, one has to ask why we do not have a total review of the way the PBS is operating, and not do it in isolation but look at the way it impacts upon other health costs. For instance, there is evidence from overseas studies that for every dollar that is spent on a PBS type scheme there can be savings of $3 to $4 in other aspects of health expenditure.

People give the simplistic reply that there is no evidence on the macrocosts of the health system, but these are things that have to be acknowledged. We have to look at the way the new generation drugs are coming onto the scheme and make an assessment about how that will actually change the need for those drugs, because it will change people's quality of life. (Extension of time granted)

I have mentioned the proposals in the budget about generic drug prescribing. There is an item in the budget entitled `Increased information provision to doctors by industry'. The opposition, at the time of the last election, indicated that we would want to have greater scrutiny of industry marketing and that we thought there should be tighter controls on direct advertising to consumers. I do not wish to make any sorts of definitive pronouncements about industry marketing, but certainly not only in the popular media but also amongst people who are more into analysing the PBS there are often concerns raised about the influence that the medical representatives employed by the pharmaceutical industry have over the prescribing habits of general practitioners.

Over time there have been a number of suggestions. Some of these have been taken up, and the scheme which allows for independent representatives is something that is well worth expanding. At one stage it was known as academic detailing, where in fact government would be the source of the provision of information to medical practitioners, that you might move to cut out the fact that the industry were out promoting the new drugs. The pharmaceutical industry has a code of conduct about its behaviour. It has an internal jurisdiction about the way it assesses complaints. If in fact this is something that the government is concerned aboutâthe opposition is certainly concerned about itâperhaps it is something we need to step back and have a look at. Perhaps there is a need to go beyond even what has been suggested by the government in the budget. The government says that this increased information provision to doctors by industry, which it estimates can be a saving of $147.1 million over four years, would be through the network of medical representatives employed by the industry. I have to say there is some concern about the behaviour of the industry in this regard, and perhaps it is now time to have a look at that.

One specific measure that was mentioned in the budget is the provision of funding for a new medical service: photodynamic therapy with verteporfinâVisudyneâtherapy, which is to do with the treatment of age related macular degeneration. The budget related papers state that there will be a special determination under the Health Insurance Act to ensure that those who might benefit will receive the therapy. I was approached by a constituent about this therapy before the budget. That constituent was very pleased that that item was contained within the budget, but in the weeks since the budget she has learned of this special determination. It has been indicated to her that perhaps she is unable to use it because of an age cut-off for use of the treatment. I am a little concerned and I require some clarification.

I want to raise only in general terms something else which is more directly related to the minister's responsibilities, and that is the provision of aged care services. In the electorate of Scullin, as has been identified by the census, the second largest ethnic group is from Macedonia. Over time, we have been trying to get an ethno-specific service in residential aged care for the Macedonian community. It has a chequered history, but some very valid and good submissions have been brought forward. I raise this matter in the context that over time I would like to hear from the minister how he perceives the way in which we might best accommodate the special needs of different ethnic communities. In the electorate of Scullin the greatest developing need is within the Macedonian community.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr ANDREWS
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: âI shall first address the final issue raised by the member for Scullin. In this year's allocation to Victoria, as he may be aware, in addition to the normal pool, 40 high-care places and 40 low-care places are allocated for people from a range of non-English-speaking backgrounds. The priority areas or ethnic groups in this instance include people from the Macedonian community. If the honourable member or representatives of the Macedonian community would like to meet with me to discuss these issues, I am most willing to ascertain a time to look at their case, as I have tried to do with some other ethnic communities in Victoria and elsewhere.

speech.para: The honourable member will be aware that the changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which have attracted the most attentionânamely, the increase in the payment for concessional and general patientsâare part of a number of changes that the government is introducing. Those changes, in the context of that package, are intended to bring about some of the results to which the honourable member alluded. That includes improving evidence based quality prescribing. We know that new medicines are included on the PBS on the basis of their clinical and cost-effectiveness and to ensure that medicines are prescribed effectively. The PBS includes rules on when and for what conditions some medicines are prescribed. This budget measure, which reinforces the commitment to evidence based medicine, includes a number of initiatives which will improve those rules and ensure that doctors prescribe in accordance with them. There are also provisions relating to the PBS listing process, the prescribing criteria, the prescriptions needing Health Insurance Commission approval and support for doctors in the community awareness program.

Secondly, there is a provision to increase information provided to doctors by the industry. There is also a measure that addresses pharmacy fraud in relation to pharmaceutical prescriptions. There is another measure relating to decreasing doctor shopping. Finally, there is a measure for facilitating the use of generic medicines. I will not rehearse all the details about these. I simply say, in response to the honourable member for Scullin, that this measure is not just about the increase in payments sought by the government for both concessional and general persons; it is also about a raft of other measures in relation to the matter.

The honourable member also spoke about reviewing the effectiveness of the PBS. I can indicate to him that the government has begun a review of the PBS program. The review is being conducted by senior officers from the departments of Health and Ageing; Prime Minister and Cabinet; Treasury; Finance; Industry, Tourism and Resources; and Veterans' Affairsâalong with officers from the Health Insurance Commission. The committee is chaired by Dr Louise Morauta, the Acting Deputy Secretary of the Department of Health and Ageing. A report is expected some time later in the year for the Minister for Health and Ageing, which may address some of the issues that the honourable member has referred to.

The other matter that the honourable member referred to was the Visudyne therapy for the treatment of macular degeneration. The funding arrangements involve payment of a health program grant to the manufacturer for the supply and distribution of the therapeutic agent associated with the therapy at no cost to the patient and for payment for the medical component of this service through the Medicare arrangements. The department is currently working with the manufacturer and the medical profession to ensure that, from 1 June this year, the treatment will be available to those patients most likely to benefit. If what I have said has not adequately addressed the honourable member's question, I will look into it further and we can perhaps provide him with some more details.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I thank the minister for that response.

âI have a series of questions that relate to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme matters that were raised in the House today but were not effectively answered by the Treasurer. I would like to raise those with the minister now. As a starting point, I note the comments that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs made about a review of the PBS. I would be interested in his comments as to why we are having a review following an announcement of a cut of over $1 billion to the scheme. It seems to me to be putting the cart before the horse. Certainly I am on the record as supporting the need for review of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, but it has to be done in the context of what is right in terms of health outcomes rather than the government trying to justify its budget cut.

speech.para: It was raised in the House today that Labor in government had always more than fully compensated pensioners through increases in the pensioners pharmaceutical allowance for any PBS copayment increases. The Treasurer did not deny that fact. I wonder whether the minister at the table could confirm it. It was also said in the House today that, if the current bill is passed, pensioners would be as much as $88.40 a year worse off because of increases in the copayment made by the Howard government since 1996. The Treasurer said no, and went on with a general diatribe about increases in the value of the age pension rather than answering the question specifically dealing with the initiative of compensation in that area.

Mr Costello was also asked which of the diabetes, asthma and arthritis drugs currently awaiting Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme listing approval would not receive that approval as a result of the threat to not list drugs in the future. I accept that is a fairly hard question to answer, but I ask the minister at the table: if the situation isâas appears to be the case in terms of the actions of the Senateâthat the government's proposal is not passed, and therefore the Treasurer's threat to the listing of drugs in the future is carried out, has any work been done on the processes that would be followed to decide which of these drugs would be denied to needy populations in the community?

I would also like the minister to comment on the Treasurer's claim that the state of the PBS at $4.2 billion a year was unsustainable, given that that is inconsistent with the advice of the former health minister, who said just last June that it was sustainable at precisely that amount. Does he agree with the previous health minister or the current Treasurer and, if so, why? I believe the Treasurer also said today that the government had a mandate to increase PBS copayments. Given the stated position of the former health minister prior to the election, and the lack, as I understand it, of any policy initiative with respect to that area during the election campaign, are we talking about a mandate on the basis of `We won, you lost'? I understand that mandate; I have been affected by it one way or another after various elections in recent times, but I am wondering whether there is anything specific that the minister could refer to which justifies this position other than the general `We won, you lost' mandate.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr ANDREWS
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: âCan I say to the honourable member for Bruce that I cannot add anything to the excellent answers that the Treasurer provided in question time today.
âI am disappointed in the minister, because I have always had a higher opinion of him than that.

âI wish to raise a couple of issues in relation to aged care, particularly in rural and regional constituencies. I wish the minister well in his new ministry and I know he is intending to travel to many of the regional areas of Australia and look at the particular problems that those communities have. One of the underlying problems that I see in relation to aged care in particularâthough there are some aspects that cover other health areasâis the fairly inflexible formula that is used for working out bed allocations for our older community. I say that fully understanding the complexities of the arrangements and the demands on the government dollar. But circumstances arise almost every year where, because of distance, remoteness and smallness, various communities are disadvantaged when it comes to looking after the aged people within their communities.

speech.para: What is tending to happen, in my view, mainly because of the economic efficiencies that can be gained, is a `feedlot' arrangement for aged people. Bigger is betterâit is more cost-effective. The most efficient way to deliver the greatest number of services to the highest number of people is to put them in some sort of feedlot arrangement, preferably high-rise where you can use some aspects of gravity to economic advantage. That is something we should guard against very carefully, particularly in regional communities. This sends a message, particularly to those small to medium communities, to leave early: `Don't wait till you are 70 to look for somewhere to retire, to look for a feedlot where you like the view of the sea, or you may have some relatives in Sydney or wherever.' It sends a signal to them to relocate during their working years so that they can re-establish themselves in another community. That creates an imbalance in the social fabric of those towns.

I know the minister is aware of that, but it is something that we have to guard against. I know that in the budget documents some money has been freed up for a four-year program that will be made available to regional communities. That is a positive aspect. In New South Wales, for instance, there were some care packages but virtually no bed allocations west of the range. That says a number of things about not only population decline in those western seats but also the inflexibility of the formula. In the major communities the bed allocation is commensurate with the formula that exists, but in other communities that is not the case.

On a more parochial basis, at a meeting recently in a small town called Bundarraâand I have raised this issue with the minister privately beforeâvirtually half the community came out to get behind an aged care facility in that particular community. There is an old hospital in that community in quite good order that does not meet the standards required for aged care. I think that is another thing we really have to look at. Maybe there should be some degree of flexibility in relation to standardsâand I know I would get struck down by lightning for saying that. We have to appreciate that some people's best accommodation is in their last years of life. Some people would accept a slightly lower standard of premise in their own community rather than a higher standard of premise in another community that was 100 kilometres away, which meant that their relatives could not get to to see them. Maybe there is some room to move in relation to that.

This community of Bundarra is a small community. It was allocated 11 beds about two years ago now. The state government has donated an old hospital building. It has raised in the vicinity of $600,000 towards a $900,000 capital improvement of the building to get it to the standard required. The challenge at the meeting the other day was for this relatively small community to raise another $100,000 on its own and it voted unanimously to accept that challenge. The federal government will be approached for some $200,000 towards the $900,000 establishment. (Extension of time granted). I think that is a classic case of smaller communities expressing some degree of independence in the sense that they are willing to get out there and take on the challenge. They just need a hand to finish the job, rather than start it. Too often communities ask governments to start and finish the process rather than, in this case, just finish it.

The other issue on aged care that really needs to be consideredâthis is clear everywhere I go, and I am sure all members of parliament agreeâis the money that is consumed in administration and the various processes that the administration people have to go through. It is getting completely out of control. I think enormous savings could be made in restoring a bit of trust in the people who look after our aged community, rather than there being this underlying assumption by the bureaucracy that they are all out to rip the system off. My view is that maybe we should accept a certain degree of improprietyâalthough that is probably not the right way to say itârather than have this totalitarian approach and the consumption of so much money just to have documents written that no-one ever reads or really takes much notice of.

The other issue that I would raise is the problem of the shortage of doctors right across regional Australia. Although the Deputy Prime Minister in particular, but also others in the parliament, have argued strongly against the use of Medicare provider numbers and differential Medicare rebates when the issue was raised in this parliament, I was very disappointed to see in the budget that they have used both those vehicles to encourage doctors into Western Sydney, Western Melbourne and other areas in the west of those major metropolitan areas.

I understand the political imperatives in relation to that, but that is not a good message to send to country communities. The Deputy Prime Minister and others have said that they will not consider geographic use of Medicare provider numbers or a differential Medicare rebate to help drive doctors to where patients are rather than to where the doctors would rather be. But these economic incentives have not been used in the country; they have been used in the western areas of our major metropolitan areas. I am not against Western Sydney getting more doctors, but we have sent a message to country doctors to go back to Sydney rather than encouraging them to look at other practices. Medical indemnity is obviously a problem that the government is wrestling with. In my view, it is doing so very slowly. I know that a lot of the insurance debate is state based, but medical indemnity is not. The federal government needs to take a greater lead in relation to that particular issue.

Rural training of doctors in recent years is a good initiative which should be encouraged. Given the fact that the medical profession and others who seem to know suggest from time to time that country kids are more likely to return to the country as doctors than are their city based cousins, maybe our vision for the future should be to have medical schools in country areas. Not only would this encourage country kids to go to that particular medical school; students who are at university in that particular location, wherever it may be, would obviously establish social contacts, maybe marital contacts, and may actually want to live in the country as medical professionals. I think we have this rather absurd structure at the moment where even the limited number of country children who do enter medicine are trained on the coast, and we then expect them all to return to the inland to practise medicine. I think we should be looking at other ways of assisting their training inland. I know this cannot be done overnight, but I think there has to be some sort of long-term view in relation to the medical profession and encouraging country children to participate in that profession.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr ANDREWS
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: âIn reply to the honourable member for New England, may I say that, having grown up in a small country town myself, I understand the sentiment which he is expressing in relation to the needs of people in smaller rural areas in terms of aged care into the future. This is a matter in which the government is obviously, on occasions, trying to balance a number of competing interests. If I could summarise it, our outlook is to try and retain the vitality of institutions and their viability into the future. Of course, a minimum number is required to keep aged care facilities economically viable, and that creates difficulties for those facilities with smaller numbers of beds. I think that leads to two other considerations. One is that we need to be flexible in the way in which we address these issues. For example, I think the multipurpose centres which are now operating in many parts of rural Australia are a flexible approach to the whole range of health and aged care needs within many rural areas. Secondly, I think there is often a need for a regional approach so that we can provide hubs and networks in which we can actually provide more services to rural areas.

speech.para: I agree with the honourable member's comments about the burden of paperwork in the aged care sector. It is something which I have addressed recently. We are doing some work on that at the present time and, hopefully, will come up with some options as to how we can uncouple the care plans from the RCSâthe classification scale for funding. We are looking to trial that either later this year or early next year, with a view to being able to put a better system into operation. I noted the honourable gentleman's other comments about a range of issues, but I will not specifically comment on them at this stage.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Gash) adjourned.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I am aware of the unfair dismissal cases at Hunter Valley No. 1 coalmine.
(2) I am aware of the unfair dismissal cases at Mount Thorley coalmine.

(3) The provisions of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 that allow appeals from decisions and orders of the Commission about unfair dismissal were not introduced by this Government, but the Keating Labor Government.

Section 45 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 provided that appeals could be made to a Full Bench of the Commission against âan award or order made by a member of the Commissionâ and that those people specified in section 170JF were entitled to appeal against unfair dismissal orders (paragraphs 45(1)(b) and (3)(aa)).

Section 170JF of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 provided that an appeal to a Full Bench could be instituted by a person entitled to apply for a variation or revocation of an order under section 170JD.

Except for a few very minor word changes, existing sections 45, 170JD and 170JF of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 mirror the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act 1988, so the laws about who may appeal and when continue to operate in the same way as the laws introduced by Labor.
(4) I understand that the parties have reached a settlement in the matter.

quote.para: (1) I am aware of the unfair dismissal cases at Hunter Valley No. 1 coalmine.

(3) The provisions of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 that allow appeals from decisions and orders of the Commission about unfair dismissal were not introduced by this Government, but the Keating Labor Government.

Section 45 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 provided that appeals could be made to a Full Bench of the Commission against âan award or order made by a member of the Commissionâ and that those people specified in section 170JF were entitled to appeal against unfair dismissal orders (paragraphs 45(1)(b) and (3)(aa)).

Section 170JF of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 provided that an appeal to a Full Bench could be instituted by a person entitled to apply for a variation or revocation of an order under section 170JD.

Except for a few very minor word changes, existing sections 45, 170JD and 170JF of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 mirror the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act 1988, so the laws about who may appeal and when continue to operate in the same way as the laws introduced by Labor.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 14 May 2002:

quote.para: How many `Work for the Dole' schemes have been funded in the electoral divisions of (a) Wills and (b) Deakin and how is the effectiveness of each project measured.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Work for the Dole activities approved since November 1997 in the electorate of Deakin number 136 and in the electorate of Wills, 215.

Community Work Coordinators (CWCs) which are contracted to develop and manage Work for the Dole activities are required to seek approval for each activity before it commences. The application requires CWCs to address three selection criteria:
Â· does the activity meet the needs of the local community;
Â· the ability of the Community Work Coordinator to monitor and support the progress of participants during their placement; and
Â· the ability to provide support to participants on completion of the project.

During the activity CWCs are contractually required to monitor each activity to ensure it is proceeding according to the approved application. In addition the department monitors a selection of activities to ensure CWCs are meeting their contractual obligations.

Within 30 days of the completion of each activity and before a final payment to the CWC can be made, CWCs are required to submit a report to the department which includes a detailed statement on the performance of the activity.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 14 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has he been briefed on a meeting held at the National Library of Australia on 8 March 2002 to discuss problems relating to the provision of library services to people with disabilities, including (a) the fact that large collections of analogue tape held by the specialist libraries for the blind and vision impaired will not be able to be accessed in three to five years time as equipment to play the tapes will no longer be manufactured, (b) the fact that these libraries do not have access to funding to facilitate the transfer of information from analogue to digital tape and (c) the need to facilitate alternative formats for students with disabilities.
(2) What work has been undertaken by Government to assist in overcoming these potential huge barriers to learning by people with disabilities.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) (a) (b) (c) The Minister for Education, Science and Training has not been briefed specifically on the meeting held by the National Library on 8 March 2002, although an officer from his Department did attend. In respect of his higher education responsibilities, the Minister has been briefed on the broad issues related to the high cost of translating written text into formats accessible by people with a visual impairment or other print handicap.

(2) The Government supports the right of children with disabilities to the same educational opportunities as other children. While the States and Territories have primary responsibility for the funding and delivery of school education, the Commonwealth provides substantial funding for both the government and non-government school sectors, which includes targeted funding to improve the educational outcomes of students with disabilities. The funding provided by the Commonwealth for students with disabilities in schools is block funding to the States and Territories and is not allocated for specific purposes. The State and Territory education authorities decide how it is to be used to support the needs of students with disabilities in their respective systems.

The Government has recognised the very high costs that some universities are bearing with regard to support for some students with disabilities, including students with a visual impairment or print handicap who require course materials and related texts in alternative formats. In the 2001 budget, the new Additional Support for Students with Disabilities Programme was announced, with some $8 million to be allocated between 2002 and 2004. The programme will commence in the second half of this year, with $1.834 million available to universities to assist with the high costs associated with supporting students with disabilities.

Officers of the Department of Education, Science and Training are monitoring the issue and participated in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's forum on the provision of alternative formats in the tertiary sector held in Sydney on 29 May 2002.

The Commonwealth continues to actively support the Regional Disability Liaison Officer (RDLO) initiative. Funded for three years at $800,000 per year, eleven RDLOs across the nation perform a range of functions, which are focused on the provision of practical assistance and support to students with disabilities to make the transition from school to TAFE or university and on to employment. RDLOs generally have a good knowledge of where students with disabilities can find information and assistance related to specific needs.

Under the national vocational education and training (VET) arrangements, funding for VET is a shared responsibility between the Commonwealth and States and Territories. State and Territory Governments are responsible for the delivery of training, including to people with disabilities. The Commonwealth provides funds for VET through the Australian National Training Authority to States and Territories. These funds supplement those provided by State and Territory Governments.

The needs of people with disabilities have been recognised. The Commonwealth and all State and Territory Ministers have signed up to implement Bridging Pathways: a National Strategy and Blueprint for people with disabilities in VET for 2000-2005 with the aim of increasing opportunities for people with disabilities in VET. The Commonwealth has provided $2 million for national actions outlined in the Blueprint. In the 2002-03 Commonwealth Budget, the Government announced that it would provide over $33 million additional funds for the VET system to meet the needs of people affected by changes to the Disability Support Pension.

This is on top of the Australians Working Together (AWT) initiative announced in the 2001-02 Commonwealth Budget, when the Commonwealth provided $24.4 million for four years from 1 July 2002 to contribute to States' and Territories' efforts to assist people with a disability to enter and complete a VET course. A Disability Coordination Officer (DCO) Programme, also announced as part of the AWT package, aims to provide information, coordination and referral services for people with a disability interested in participating in post-school education and training and to assist them to succeed in their chosen studies. The DCO Programme will commence on 1 July 2002.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 15 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is he aware of the Australian Standard for Glass in Buildings AS1288 Review.
(2) Will these changes cause the leadlighting industry to end and over 2000 small businesses to close.
(3) Why does leadlight need to be triple glazed.
(4) How will heritage buildings have their leadlight windows repaired or replaced.
(5) Why is there no standard for leadlight glazing in the proposed amendments.
(6) Why does leadlight have to be covered by other âbrittleâ glass when there is no evidence held by the Australian Bureau of Statistics of any injuries caused by human impact with leaded glass.
(7) What statistics necessitated the covering and changing of the codes for leadlight.

(8) Why do precautions have to be taken to provide mechanical protection to glazing in critical locations; or enhancing a person's awareness of the presence of glass by making it visible, when leadlight, with its composition of lead and colour, does just that.
(9) Why is safety glass required when leadlight, by virtue of its construction, minimises the risk of cutting or piercing injuries.
(10) Why does the area covered for human impact safety requirements go from 500mm off the floor to 2000mm off the floor, an increase of 400% in height.
(11) Why does the minimum glass requirements for windows above 500mm off the floor increase from 3mm to 5mm laminated glass or 4mm toughened.
(12) What statistics prompted these changes and if they show an increase in accidents, are they relevant proportional figures.
(13) Why does glass below 2000mm need to be specially toughened or laminated.
(14) Does the Standard refer to windows; if so, how frequently.
(15) Is it the policy of the Standards Committee to adopt or move toward international standards; if so, why is there a different or lesser standard for New Zealand.

(16) Does 3mm float glass currently cost $16.45 per square metre while 5mm laminated glass currently costs $64.24 per square metre; if so, which interests represented on the committee will benefit most by the new Standard.
(17) Has it taken years to formulate the new standard; if so, why is there such a short time for (a) submissions for changes and (b) the Standard to be implemented.

(18) Does the Standards Committee have before it a draft document on Standards for Leadlighting which it approved on 23 January 2002; if so, why was that draft not released as part of the draft for the AS1288 review.
(19) Why will the project 3405 document be released for public comment on 26 July 2002 when the closure date for the review of AS1288 Review is 30 May 2002.
(20) If leadlight is to be covered under AS1288, and the Standards Committee already has a review document for leadlight, should leadlight be reviewed in the same time frame within the same document.

(21) Is it the case that leadlight which is not produced by a large glass manufacturer and found in some of the largest windows in towns and cities in Australia, including church windows, is condemned and omitted in the Standards Review, while products of the large glass manufacturers are liberally looked after with requirements such as toughened glass having to be treated by a large company and the use of expensive laminated glass compared to the glass presently used.
(22) Is Pilkington Glass represented on the Committee; if so, did it unload its stained glass stocks at the same time as AS1288 Review was released for public comment.

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(2) No. The proposed changes to the draft standard will only affect leadlight used in installations where there are human impact requirements, however it will have no effect when used outside these areas.
(3) It is proposed that leadlight glazing in high-risk areas, eg doors etc, ought to be protected by triple glazing only where there is a risk of human impact.
(4) The revised standard will not apply in those circumstances where human impact is not at risk. Most applications in heritage buildings would fall outside the coverage of the standard.

(5) Draft standard, AS 1288.2 - Lead light and stained glass construction and installation, is being prepared dealing with construction and installation of leadlight glazing and stained glass and is expected to be released for public comment on 4 June 2002.
(6) The aim of the standard is to enhance the level of safety around all glazed installations where there is a potential risk of injury.
(7) Standards for human impact are moving towards higher levels of public safety and minimising potential risk.
(8) There is no requirement in the draft standard to enhance visibility of leadlight glazing.
(9) The breakage characteristics of annealed glass in lead light may cause cutting and serious injuries.
(10) This provision applies to bathrooms, en suites and spa rooms and is intended to ensure that on every occasion the appropriate level of safety is built into the window provided.
(11) The issue is one of safety, taking into consideration the breakage characteristics of annealed glass.
(12) Standards for human impact are moving towards higher levels of public safety and minimising potential risk.
(13) In the event of accidental human contact, the use of toughened or safety glass represents less of a risk of injury.
(14) Yes. The word âwindowâ is referred to five times in the text, and once in a figure, of the draft standard AS 1288.1; and once in the text of the draft standard AS 1288.2.
(15) Yes. It is not in the interest of public safety to lower performance characteristics when the higher standard is already accepted in the market place.

(16) The costs for glass is a commercial matter and subject to market pressures from time to time. Those interests on the committee concerned with public safety will benefit most from the proposed changes.
(a) The period for comment (two months) complies with Standards Australia policy. Extensions are allowed in the case of relevant stakeholders requesting to make additional submissions.
(b) The draft standards have not been implemented. There is no time limit on committee consideration of stakeholder comments to reach consensus.

(18) The leadlight draft standard AS 1288.2 was approved by the committee for release as a draft on 3 May 2002 (not 23 January) and is expected to be released for public comment on 4 June 2002, closing on 6 August 2002. The second draft standard, AS 1288.2, was not finalised when the draft revision of AS 1288 - 1994 (AS 1288.1) was ready for public comment.
(19) See response to Question 18.

(20) The review of AS 1288 will result in the publication of two documents. AS 1288.1 deals mainly with safety issues related to general glass installations whilst AS 1288.2 will deal with the construction and installations of leadlight. The two new standards are being prepared in parallel but not together.
(21) The proposed new requirements in AS 1288.2 apply only to leadlight applications where there is a risk of human impact.

(22) Glass manufacturers, along with other key stakeholders and regulators, are represented on the committee to provide a balance of interests and views. I am unable to comment on the commercial activities of the company.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 27 May 2002:

quote.para: What action is being taken to bring the Extreme Disablement Adjustment (EDA) up to the same level as the Totally and Permanently Incapacitated (TPI) entitlement.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Totally and Permanently Incapacitated (T&PI) benefit and Extreme Disablement Adjustment (EDA) serve different purposes. The higher rate of benefit provided to T&PI recipients recognises that they have generally been financially disadvantaged because their working lives have been cut short by their war or defence caused injuries. By contrast, EDA is designed for those elderly and frail veterans who are severely incapacitated by their war or defence caused injuries.

However, earlier this year I appointed a high profile and independent committee to examine perceived anomalies in the eligibility criteria for benefits under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The Committee will also consider submissions made by interested parties as to the structure and appropriateness of disability compensation pensions, including EDA.
The Committee will report to me no later than mid-November 2002.
